instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this lineâ€™s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Battery Detection
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Battery Detection

I have noticed:

<RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> has a resistance of 1.5 instead of 2 , resistor itself is fine

Testting at <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> seems to be where the problem lies if I am not mistaken.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_GH3</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> = 2.6V

What controls <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>?

I am relatively new, I apologize if I ask any "dumb" questions.

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Battery Detection
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>/81 are the pull-up resistors for SM Battery Bus.
Check resistance to ground on both lines.
Diode mode, red probe to ground; must get less than 0.5-1% difference...

If notice difference, remove <DIODE>D6950</DIODE> and check again.
First of all, disconnect BIL conector, J6955.
Post the values found.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Battery Detection
threads.message:
Diode Mode:
<RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> - .516
<RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> - .607

Diode Mode after Removing <DIODE>D6950</DIODE>:
<RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> - .480
<RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> - .574

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Battery Detection
threads.message:
Still bad...
Did you disconnect J6955?
Next step, desolder <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>, let the board cool down and measure again.
If still get difference, SMC issue...
You can try reflow SMC first, or reball it.
But you'll need to change it I suppose.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Battery Detection
threads.message:
Okay sounds good - Ty

Is ti worth trying to inject voltage into the line and looking for heat/short?
